,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: '''Marko Tapani \"Marco\" Hietala''' (born 14 January 1966) is a Finnish [[Heavy metal music
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: heavy metal]] vocalist, bassist and songwriter. Internationally, he is most known as the current bassist, male vocalist and secondary composer to [[Tuomas Holopainen]], of the [[symphonic metal]] band [[Nightwish]].<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Nightwish: Video Interview With Marco Hietala Posted Online
column11: archivedate=June 6, 2011}}</ref> He is also the vocalist and bassist as well as composer and lyricist for the heavy metal band [[Tarot (band)
column14: title=Tarot's New Album Lands on Finnish Chart

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: He is also a member of the [[Supergroup (music)
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: supergroup]] [[Northern Kings]], and portrayed one of the main characters in [[Ayreon]]'s 2013 album ''[[The Theory of Everything (Ayreon album)

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Marco Hietala was born in [[Tervo]], and is the youngest child of the Hietala family. Hietala lived in [[Tervo]] until the age of 15, after which he moved to [[Kuopio]] to study classical guitar, vocals and musical theory in high school. In 1984, he and his brother, [[Zachary Hietala]], formed heavy metal band [[Tarot (band)
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Tarot]] under the name ''Purgatory''. In 1986, Tarot received a deal for their [[Spell of Iron
column3: first album]] and went on tour.<ref>{{cite web
column10: archivedate=April 10, 2012}}</ref> Before becoming a full-time musician, he worked as a live and studio sound engineer.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Nightwish: Floor Jansen, Tuomas Holopainen and Marco Hietala on making the cut as a musician

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Hietala joined Nightwish in 2001 when Tuomas Holopainen and the band's manager called him and said that there would be a place in the band for a vocalist and a bass player.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: url-status=dead }}</ref> ''[[Century Child]]'' was his first Nightwish album, following the departure of previous bassist [[Sami Vänskä]].<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Sinergy Singer, Former Bassist Issue Separate Statements Regarding Split
column16: archivedate=June 6, 2011}}</ref> He was a prominent guest musician in [[Delain]], a project involving many members of the [[gothic metal
column26: archivedate=March 16, 2010}}</ref> He also participated in the recording of ''[[Invitation (Altaria album)
column30: title=Altaria Complete Recording, Begin Mixing Full-Length Debut
column37: archivedate=June 6, 2011}}</ref> Hietala has also been part of the bands [[Sinergy]] and [[Northern Kings]].<ref>{{cite web
column39: title=Northern Kings Performs at Finnish 'Eurovision Song Contest' Finals

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Upon his arrival to Nightwish, several songs were written to contain duets with then [[Nightwish]] vocalist [[Tarja Turunen]], allowing songwriter and band leader [[Tuomas Holopainen]] to take advantage of Hietala's distinctive raucous voice to add a new dimension to the band. A famous example is Nightwish's cover of \"The Phantom of the Opera,\" from the album \"Century Child.\"

During Nightwish's shows, Turunen would take a break halfway through the set. Before Hietala joined the band, the band would perform an instrumental song during this time. After Hietala joined the band, they performed covers of well-known songs, with Hietala singing the lead vocal part in this break. The band has performed [[Ozzy Osbourne]]'s \"[[Crazy Train]]\", [[W.A.S.P. (band)
column3: Dio]]'s \"Don't Talk to Strangers\", [[Megadeth]]'s \"[[Symphony of Destruction]]\" and [[Pink Floyd]]'s \"[[High Hopes (Pink Floyd song)
column4: High Hopes]]\". Some of these songs have been put up for sale as well on various Nightwish album releases. Following Turunen's departure from Nightwish, Hietala was much more involved with the production of ''[[Dark Passion Play]]'', which was released in September 2007. He sang some songs, completely, and wrote the music for the song \"[[The Islander (song)
column5: The Islander]]\", on which he also plays acoustic guitar instead of bass. Hietala is also credited alongside [[Tuomas Holopainen
column6: Holopainen]] for co-writing the song \"[[The Crow, the Owl and the Dove]]\" from Nightwish's 2011 album, ''[[Imaginaerum]]''.

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In [[Delain]], Hietala played bass for the album ''[[Lucidity (album)
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Lucidity]]'' and was also the main male vocalist on the album with featured vocals on the song ''The Gathering''. He is also featured as vocalist in two of the songs on [[Delain]]'s second album ''[[April Rain]]'' and two songs from [[Delain]]'s fourth album ''[[The Human Contradiction]]''.

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In March 2009, Hietala joined the band [[Sapattivuosi]]. They cover [[Black Sabbath]] songs in Finnish.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Marco Hietala's Black Sabbath Tribute Band To Play in Poland
column10: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In this band, however, Hietala does not play bass; he only performs vocals.

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: On 1 April 2010 it was said that Hietala would leave the band to concentrate on a [[choir]] career.  This was identified as an April Fool's joke, but was also a reference to his participation in ''Kuorosota'' (the localized Finnish version of ''[[Clash of the Choirs]]'') in 2010.  Hietala was the master of the [[Kuopio]] choir in the program's second season.  He came second in the contest, losing in the finals to the [[Joensuu]] choir, headed by pop rock singer [[Ilkka Alanko]].  Tarot's single \"I Walk Forever,\" from the ''[[Gravity of Light (Tarot album)
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Gravity of Light]]'' album, was performed for the first time by Hietala, [[Tommi Salmela
column3: Tommi \"Tuple\" Salmela]] and the Kuopio choir during Kuorosota 2010; other songs performed included \"[[The Phantom of the Opera (Andrew Lloyd Webber song)
column4: The Phantom of the Opera]],\" which Hietala has covered with Nightwish as well.

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In June 2010, Hietala joined the heavy metal supergroup HAIL! on two occasions, performing [[Black Sabbath]]'s [[Neon Knights]] with [[Tim \"Ripper\" Owens
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Ripper Owens]], [[Andreas Kisser]], [[James LoMenzo]] and [[Paul Bostaph]] at two of their shows in [[Finland]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=HAIL! Performs With NIGHTWISH's MARCO HIETALA at Finland's SAUNA OPEN AIR

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: On 14 August 2013 Hietala was the first singer to be confirmed by [[Arjen Anthony Lucassen
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Arjen Lucassen]] to guest on [[Ayreon]]'s new album [[The Theory of Everything (Ayreon album)
column5: title=Marco Hietala guests on Ayreon Theory of Everything

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Hietala released his first solo album ''Mustan sydämen rovio'' in May 2019. He released the album under his birthname Marko Hietala and will be using the name also in his other projects in the future. Hietala has described his solo material as \"hard [[progressive rock
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: prog]]\".<ref name=\"yle3-10761251\">https://yle.fi/uutiset/3-10761251</ref> An English version of the album, titled ''[[Pyre of the Black Heart]]'' ([[Nuclear Blast]]), followed in January 2020.<ref name=\"nuclearblast\">https://www.nuclearblast.de/en/label/music/band/news/details/6361050.6134325.marko-hietala-announce-first-solo-album.html</ref> Joining him on the albums are drummer [[Anssi Nykänen]], keyboardist [[Vili Ollila]] and guitarist [[Tuomas Wäinölä]] with whom he also toured in Finland in the summer and autum of 2019.<ref name=\"yle3-10761251\" /> The band will embark on a European tour in February 2020.<ref name=\"nuclearblast\" />

Warwick]] bass guitars, particularly the Infinity NT (birdseye maple top) and Vampyre NT (flame maple top) 4-string models tuned D Standard (DGCF) and Drop C (CGCF). He also owns a Warwick Buzzard JE with a rusty finish equipped with a detuner (Used, among others, in the music videoes for Elan and Endless Forms Most Beautiful), and a Kramer bass. He uses Warwick's Hellborg amplifier and cabs. After joining Nightwish he used a SansAmp GT2 distortion pedal for some time. ¨¨

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Hietala also uses a custom made Warwick/Framus doubleneck bass/electric guitar, based on the Warwick Infinity.

From Century Child until the End of an Era Hietala used an Infinity almost exclusively for live and studio applications. Later, the Vampyre became his axe of choice (almost for the whole period with Anette as Nightwish's vocalist). The first time he can be seen with a Vampyre is the Bye Bye Beautiful music video. From the Imaginaerum tour going forward Buzzard became his preferred brand, but occasionally he still can be seen with an Infinity.

Hietala has stated that the biggest influence on him as a bassist is [[Geezer Butler]] and [[Bob Daisley]], while [[Ronnie James Dio]] and [[Rob Halford]] are his biggest influence as a vocalist. He has also stated that he listens to wide array of music ranging from \"really sensitive stuff to a lot of really hard stuff\", saying that he \"tend[s] to soak up almost everything\" which \"somehow ends up being used\" when he writes his own music.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=~ Wings of Darkness ~ The Official Tarot Website

2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: ''How is your musical taste towards metal music / other genres?''
column3: author=Question on the official Tarot website (2006)}}

2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: ''Anything works for me, if it's good enough. I'm mainly a metalhead, but I have this basic respect for any kind of music. Writing and listening to music would become stale if I couldn't draw influences from other styles too.''

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Hietala has two children with his ex-wife Manki, twin boys Antto and Miro. He and his family currently live in [[Kuopio]], Finland. When he is not touring, he enjoys reading books, playing video games, and watching movies. He especially likes [[fantasy]], horror and science fiction books. In 2016, a Finnish newspaper reported that Hietala had filed for divorce.<ref>[http://www.is.fi/viihde/art-2000001177177.html]</ref> In August 2018 he married Camila Cavalcanti<ref>[https://www.seiska.fi/Uutiset/Vau-mika-morsian-Kesalla-avioitunut-Nightwish-Marco-ja-Cami-vaimo-juhlivat-naimisiinmenoaan]</ref>

Later, the Vampyre became his axe of choice (almost for the whole period with Anette as Nightwish's vocalist). The first time he can be seen with a Vampyre is the Bye Bye Beautiful music video. From the Imaginaerum tour going forward Buzzard became his preferred brand, but occasionally he still can be seen with an Infinity.

Hietala has stated that the biggest influence on him as a bassist is [[Geezer Butler]] and [[Bob Daisley]], while [[Ronnie James Dio]] and [[Rob Halford]] are his biggest influence as a vocalist. He has also stated that he listens to wide array of music ranging from \"really sensitive stuff to a lot of really hard stuff\", saying that he \"tend[s] to soak up almost everything\" which \"somehow ends up being used\" when he writes his own music.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=~ Wings of Darkness ~ The Official Tarot Website

2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: ''How is your musical taste towards metal music / other genres?''
column3: author=Question on the official Tarot website (2006)}}

2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: ''Anything works for me, if it's good enough. I'm mainly a metalhead, but I have this basic respect for any kind of music. Writing and listening to music would become stale if I couldn't draw influences from other styles too.''

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Hietala has two children with his ex-wife Manki, twin boys Antto and Miro. He and his family currently live in [[Kuopio]], Finland. When he is not touring, he enjoys reading books, playing video games, and watching movies. He especially likes [[fantasy]], horror and science fiction books. In 2016, a Finnish newspaper reported that Hietala had filed for divorce.<ref>[http://www.is.fi/viihde/art-2000001177177.html]</ref> In August 2018 he married Camila Cavalcanti<ref>[https://www.seiska.fi/Uutiset/Vau-mika-morsian-Kesalla-avioitunut-Nightwish-Marco-ja-Cami-vaimo-juhlivat-naimisiinmenoaan]</ref>

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: The '''Fifth Crusade''' (1217–1221) was an attempt by Western Europeans to reacquire [[Jerusalem]] and the rest of the [[Holy Land]] by first conquering [[Cairo]], the capital of the powerful [[Ayyubid]] state in [[Egypt]].

[[Pope Innocent III]] and his successor [[Pope Honorius III]] organized crusading armies led by King [[Andrew II of Hungary]] and [[Leopold VI, Duke of Austria]], and an attack against [[Jerusalem]] ultimately left the city in Muslim hands.  Later in 1218, a German army led by [[Oliver of Paderborn]], and a mixed army of [[Dutch people
column4: Frisian]] soldiers led by [[William I, Count of Holland]] joined the crusade. In order to attack [[Damietta]] in Egypt, they allied in [[Anatolia]] with the [[Seljuk Sultanate of Rûm]] under [[Kaykaus I]] and attacked the Ayyubids in Syria in an attempt to free the Crusaders from fighting on two fronts.

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: After occupying the port of [[Damietta]], the Crusaders marched south towards Cairo in July 1221. On the way, they laid siege to [[Aswan]] from the north side, but were turned back after they were trapped and their dwindling supplies led to a forced retreat. Sultan [[al-Kamil]] ordered the destruction of the dam blocking the Nile River which lead to the flooding of the Crusader camp. They retreated to a nearby hilltop where they resisted to the point of starvation. The siege resulted in a great number of Crusader losses, and eventually in the surrender of the army. Al-Kamil forced Europe to retreat from Damietta - and Egypt altogether - and to an eight-year peace agreement.

[[Pope Innocent III]] had already planned since 1208 a crusade to recapture Jerusalem. In April 1213 he issued the [[papal bull]] ''[[Quia maior]]'', calling all of Christendom to join a new [[crusade]].<ref>{{Cite journal
column5: title=How to craft a crusade call: Pope Innocent III and Quia maior (1213)
column12: issn=1468-2281}}</ref> This was followed by another papal bull, the ''Ad Liberandam'' in 1215.<ref name=\"cf\">{{Citation
column15: title=God's war: a new history of the Crusades

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: The message of the crusade was preached in France by [[Robert of Courçon]]; unlike other Crusades, few French knights joined, as they were already fighting the [[Albigensian Crusade]] against the [[Heresy

In 1215 Pope Innocent III summoned the [[Fourth Lateran Council]], where, along with the [[Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem]], [[Raoul of Merencourt]], he discussed the recovery of the Holy Land, among other church business. Pope Innocent wanted it to be led by the [[papacy]], as the [[First Crusade]] should have been, to avoid the mistakes of the [[Fourth Crusade]], which had been taken over by the [[Venice
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Venetians]]. Pope Innocent planned for the crusaders to meet at [[Brindisi]] in 1216, and prohibited trade with the Muslims, to ensure that the crusaders would have ships and weapons. Every crusader would receive an [[indulgence]], including those who simply helped pay the expenses of a crusader, but did not go on crusade themselves.

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: [[Oliver of Paderborn]] had preached the crusade in [[Holy Roman Empire]], and [[Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Emperor Frederick II]] attempted to join in 1215. Frederick was the last monarch Innocent wanted to join, as he had challenged the [[Papacy]] (and would do so in the years to come). Innocent died in 1216 and was succeeded by [[Pope Honorius III]], who barred Frederick from participating, but organized crusading armies led by King [[Andrew II of Hungary]] and [[Leopold VI, Duke of Austria]]. Andrew was estimated to have the largest royal army in the history of the crusades. (Stated strengths of 20,000 knights, 12,000 castle-garrisons and 200,000 foot soldiers were likely an exaggeration).<ref>Wolff, Robert L. and Hazard, H. W., ''A History of the Crusades: Volume Two, The Later Crusades 1187-1311'', The University of Wisconsin Press, Madison, 1977, pg. 389</ref>

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: According to [[Oliver of Paderborn]], the ''[[Gesta crucignorum rhenanorum]] '' and ''[[De itinere frisonum]]'', many of the Crusaders from the [[Rhineland]], [[Flanders]], and [[Friesland]] decided to go to the [[Holy Land]] by their traditional sea journey. The fleet made their first stop at [[Dartmouth, Devon
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Dartmouth]] on the southern coast of England. There they elected their leaders and the laws by which they would organize their venture. From there led by Counts [[William I of Holland]] and [[George of Weid]] they continued on their way south to Lisbon. As in previous crusading seaborne journeys, the fleet was dispersed by storms and only gradually managed to reach the Portuguese city of Lisbon after making a stopover at the famous shrine of [[Santiago de Compostela]].<ref>Villegas-Aristizábal, Lucas, \"A Frisian Perspective on Crusading in Iberia as Part of the Sea Journey to the Holy Land 1217-1218\", ''Studies in Medieval and Renaissance History'' 15 (2019)</ref>

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: At their arrival in Portugal as during the second Crusade, the Bishop of Lisbon and other members of the Portuguese clergy attempted to persuade the crusaders to help them capture the [[Almohad]] controlled city of [[Alcácer do Sal]]. The [[Frisians]] according to ''[[De itinere frisonum]],'' however, refused on account of [[Innocent III]]'s disqualification of the venture at the [[Fourth Lateran Council]].<ref>Villegas-Aristizábal, Lucas, \"Was the Portuguese Led Military Campaign against Alcácer do Sal in the Autumn of 1217 Part of the Fifth Crusade?\", ''Al-Masaq'' 30:1 (2019), 62. https://doi.org/10.1080/09503110.2018.1542573</ref> The other members of the fleet, however, were convinced by the Portuguese and started the siege of the city in August 1217. The Crusaders finally captured [[Alcácer do Sal]] with the help of the [[Military order (religious society)
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: military orders]] on October 1217, after they repel an attempt by the governors of [[Seville]], [[Badajoz]], and [[Jaén, Spain
column3: Jaén]] to relieve the besieged garrison. According to William of Holland in his letter to [[Pope Honorius III]] the Almohad leader of the garrison with 2000 of his followers converted to Christianity after they had surrendered the town to the crusading forces. From there on the Crusading fleet continued on its journey to the Levant.<ref>Villegas-Aristizábal, Lucas, \"Was the Portuguese Led Military Campaign against Alcácer do Sal in the Autumn of 1217 Part of the Fifth Crusade?\", ''Al-Masaq'' 30:1 (2019), 64. https://doi.org/10.1080/09503110.2018.1542573</ref>

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Pope Innocent had managed to secure Georgia's participation in the crusade. Georgia's largely isolationist policies had allowed it to accumulate a powerful army and a very large concentration of knights. However, the reconnaissance force under the Mongols [[Jebe]] and [[Subutai]] destroyed the entire Georgian army in two successive battles, most notably at the [[Battle of Khunan]] in 1222.  After the death of Georgian King [[George IV of Georgia
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: George IV Lasha]], his sister [[Rusudan of Georgia
column3: Queen Rusudan]] wrote to the Pope informing him that Georgia was unable to fulfill its promise to assist in the Crusade because its army had been destroyed by unknown savages. It has been speculated that the oddly passive behavior of the Crusaders in the later years was due to them waiting for the Georgian army to join the fray.<ref>Frank McLynn, Genghis Khan. DaCapo Press (2015), 322-327.</ref>

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Decades after this Crusade, Mongol ruler Hulegu Khan would take a census of the Kingdom of Georgia to ascertain how many troops it could muster. According to contemporary sources, the kingdom was judged to be able to field nine tumens.<ref>M.F. Brosset, \"Historie de la Georgie,\" I (St. Petersburg, 1849), pp. 548-549.</ref> A tumen was nominally 10,000 men, but usually averaged 5,000 in reality.<ref>David Morgan, \"The Mongols,\" 1986, p. 72. Morgan expresses skepticism that a tumen actually consisted of 10,000 men and notes that most were 3,000 to 7,000 men.</ref> If Hulegu's census was accurate, then the kingdom of Georgia in the 13th century was capable of mustering 45,000 soldiers. Had a force this size joined the Fifth Crusade, it would have more than doubled the Crusaders' strength.

The first to take up the cross in the Fifth Crusade was King [[Andrew II of Hungary]].<ref>[[Alexander Mikaberidze]]: ''Conflict and Conquest in the Islamic World: A Historical Encyclopedia'', Volume 1 (page 311)</ref> In July 1217, Andrew departed from [[Zagreb]], accompanied by [[Leopold VI of Austria]] and [[Otto I, Duke of Merania]].{{sfn
column8: p=133}} King Andrew's army was so large{{mdash}}at least 10,000 mounted soldiers and even much more \"uncountable\" infantrymen{{mdash}}that most of it stayed behind when Andrew and his men embarked in Split two months later.{{sfn
column14: pp=147–148}} They were transported by the [[Republic of Venice
column15: Venetian]] fleet, which was the largest European fleet in the era. {{sfn
column18: p=297}} Andrew and his troops embarked on 23 August 1217, in [[Split, Croatia
column19: Split]]. They landed on 9 October on [[Cyprus]] from where they sailed to [[Acre, Israel
column20: Acre]] and joined [[John of Brienne]], ruler of the [[Kingdom of Jerusalem]], [[Hugh I of Cyprus]], and Prince [[Bohemond IV of Antioch]] to fight against the [[Ayyubids]] in [[Syria]]. Until his return to Hungary, King Andrew remained the leader of Christian forces in the Fifth Crusade.<ref>Thomas Keightley, Dionysius Lardner: ''Outlines of history: from the earliest period to the present time'' (page 210)</ref> In October 1217, the leaders of the crusaders - Masters of Hospitallers, Templars and Teutonic knights with the leaders and dignitaries of the crusade - held a war council in Acre, over which King Andrew II presided.<ref>Kenneth M. Setton, Norman P. Zacour, Harry W. Hazard: ''A History of the Crusades: The Impact of the Crusades on the Near East'' (page 358)</ref>

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: King Andrew's well-mounted army defeated sultan [[Al-Adil I]] at [[Bethsaida]] on the [[Jordan River]] on 10 November 1217. Muslim forces retreated in their fortresses and towns. In Jerusalem, the walls and fortifications were demolished to prevent the Christians from being able to defend the city, if they did manage to reach it and take it. Muslims fled the city, afraid that there would be a repeat of the bloodbath of the [[First Crusade]] in 1099. The crusaders' catapults and [[trebuchet]]s did not arrive in time, so they had fruitless assaults on the fortresses of the [[Lebanon]] and on [[Mount Tabor]]. Afterwards, Andrew spent his time collecting alleged relics. At the beginning of 1218 Andrew, who was very sick, decided to return to Hungary.<ref>(Jean Richard: ''The Crusades'', c 1071-c. 1291) page 298.</ref><ref name=Howard>{{cite book
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: title= The Crusades: A History of One of the Most Epic Military Campaigns of All Time
column5: publisher= BookCaps Study Guides [for Kindle; Golgotha Press for paperback]

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Andrew and his army departed to Hungary in February 1218, and Bohemund and Hugh also returned home.<ref name=Howard/>
Later in 1218 Oliver of Cologne arrived with a new German army and the count of Holland [[William I, Count of Holland
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: William I]] arrived with a mixed army consisting of [[Dutch people
column5: Frisian]] soldiers. With Leopold and John they discussed attacking [[Damietta]] in Egypt. To accomplish this, they allied with [[Kaykaus I]], Seljuq Sultan of Rûm in [[Anatolia]], who attacked the Ayyubids in Syria in an attempt to free the Crusaders from fighting on two fronts.<ref>{{cite book
column7: title=The 14th and Final Crusade to the Middle East: Crusades from the 11th Century to the 21st Century
column15: title= A Clash of Thrones: The Power-crazed Medieval Kings, Popes and Emperors of Europe
column23: title= Afghanistan's Experiences: The History of the Most Horrifying Events Involving Politics, Religion, and Terrorism

2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: title= Franks and Saracens: Reality and Fantasy in the Crusades and Terrorism

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In July 1218 the crusaders began their [[Siege of Damietta (1218–19)
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: siege of Damietta]], and despite resistance from the unprepared sultan [[Al-Adil]], the tower outside the city was taken on August 25. They could not gain Damietta itself, and in the ensuing months diseases killed many of the crusaders, including [[Robert of Courçon]]. Al-Adil also died and was succeeded by [[al-Kamil]]. Meanwhile, Honorius III sent [[Pelagius of Albano]] to lead the crusade in 1219 . Al-Kamil tried to negotiate peace with the crusaders. He offered to trade [[Damietta]] for [[Jerusalem]], but Pelagius would not accept these offers. After hearing this [[William I, Count of Holland]] left the crusade and sailed home.  In August or September, [[Francis of Assisi]] arrived in the crusader camp and crossed over to preach to al-Kamil. By November, the crusaders had worn out the sultan's forces, and were finally able to occupy the port.

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Immediately the papal and secular powers fought for control of the town, with [[John of Brienne]] claiming it for himself in 1220. Pelagius would not accept this, and John returned to Acre later that year. Pelagius hoped Frederick II would arrive with a fresh army, but he never did; instead, after a year of inactivity in both Syria and Egypt, [[John of Brienne]] returned.

Then in July 1221, excited by rumors that the army of one King David, a descendant of the legendary [[Prester John]], was on its way from the east to the Holy Land to join the crusade, the crusaders at Damietta marched south towards [[Cairo]].<ref>Christopher Eric Taylor, ''Waiting for Prester John: The Legend, the Fifth Crusade, and Medieval Christian Holy War'', 2011, University of Texas at Austin.</ref> This move was observed by the forces of al-Kamil, and frequent raids along the flanks of the army led to the withdrawal of some 2000 German troops who refused to continue the advance and returned to Damietta.

By now al-Kamil was able to ally with the other [[Ayyubid]]s in Syria, who had defeated [[Kaykaus I]]. The crusader march to [[Cairo]] was disastrous; the river [[Nile]] flooded ahead of them, stopping the crusader advance. A dry canal that they had previously crossed by flooded, thus blocking the crusader army's retreat. With supplies dwindling, a forced retreat began, culminating in a nighttime attack by Al-Kamil which resulted in a great number of crusader losses and eventually in the surrender of the army under Pelagius.

The terms of this surrender meant the relinquishing of [[Damietta]] to al-Kamil in exchange for the release of the crusaders. Al-Kamil agreed to an eight-year peace agreement with Europe and to return a piece of the [[True Cross]]. However, the relic was never returned as al-Kamil did not, in fact, have it.

The failure of the Crusade caused an outpouring of anti-papal sentiment from the [[Occitan]] poet [[Guilhem Figueira]]. The more orthodox [[Gormonda de Monpeslier]] responded to Figueira's ''D'un sirventes far'' with a song of her own, ''Greu m'es a durar''. Instead of blaming Pelagius or the Papacy, she laid the blame on the \"foolishness\" of the wicked.

The ''[[Palästinalied]]'' is a famous lyric poem by [[Walther von der Vogelweide]] written in [[Middle High German]] describing a [[pilgrim]] travelling to the [[Holy Land]] during the height of the Fifth Crusade.<ref>Kaye, Haley Caroline, \"The Troubadours and the Song of the Crusades\" (2016).Senior Projects Spring 2016.Paper 280. http://digitalcommons.bard.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1171&context=senproj_s2016. (Pages 70-77)</ref>
*Cassidy-Welch, Megan. ''War and Memory at the Time of the Fifth Crusade''. Pennsylvania State University Press, 2019.
*Donovan, Joseph P. ''Pelagius and the Fifth Crusade''. University of Pennsylvania Press, 2016 [1950].
*Perry, Guy. ''John of Brienne: King of Jerusalem, Emperor of Constantinople, c. 1175–1237''. Cambridge University Press, 2013.
*Powell, James M. ''Anatomy of a Crusade, 1213–1221''. University of Pennsylvania Press, 1986.

2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Tolan, John V.]] ''Saint Francis and the Sultan: The Curious History of a Christian–Muslim Encounter''. Oxford University Press, 2009.

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: *Van Cleve, Thomas C. \"The Fifth Crusade\". Madison, Wisconsin: University of Wisconsin Press, 1969.

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: At their arrival in Portugal as during the second Crusade, the Bishop of Lisbon and other members of the Portuguese clergy attempted to persuade the crusaders to help them capture the [[Almohad]] controlled city of [[Alcácer do Sal]]. The [[Frisians]] according to ''[[De itinere frisonum]],'' however, refused on account of [[Innocent III]]'s disqualification of the venture at the [[Fourth Lateran Council]].<ref>Villegas-Aristizábal, Lucas, \"Was the Portuguese Led Military Campaign against Alcácer do Sal in the Autumn of 1217 Part of the Fifth Crusade?\", ''Al-Masaq'' 30:1 (2019), 62. https://doi.org/10.1080/09503110.2018.1542573</ref> The other members of the fleet, however, were convinced by the Portuguese and started the siege of the city in August 1217. The Crusaders finally captured [[Alcácer do Sal]] with the help of the [[Military order (religious society)
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: military orders]] on October 1217, after they repel an attempt by the governors of [[Seville]], [[Badajoz]], and [[Jaén, Spain
column3: Jaén]] to relieve the besieged garrison. According to William of Holland in his letter to [[Pope Honorius III]] the Almohad leader of the garrison with 2000 of his followers converted to Christianity after they had surrendered the town to the crusading forces. From there on the Crusading fleet continued on its journey to the Levant.<ref>Villegas-Aristizábal, Lucas, \"Was the Portuguese Led Military Campaign against Alcácer do Sal in the Autumn of 1217 Part of the Fifth Crusade?\", ''Al-Masaq'' 30:1 (2019), 64. https://doi.org/10.1080/09503110.2018.1542573</ref>

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Pope Innocent had managed to secure Georgia's participation in the crusade. Georgia's largely isolationist policies had allowed it to accumulate a powerful army and a very large concentration of knights. However, the reconnaissance force under the Mongols [[Jebe]] and [[Subutai]] destroyed the entire Georgian army in two successive battles, most notably at the [[Battle of Khunan]] in 1222.  After the death of Georgian King [[George IV of Georgia
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: George IV Lasha]], his sister [[Rusudan of Georgia
column3: Queen Rusudan]] wrote to the Pope informing him that Georgia was unable to fulfill its promise to assist in the Crusade because its army had been destroyed by unknown savages. It has been speculated that the oddly passive behavior of the Crusaders in the later years was due to them waiting for the Georgian army to join the fray.<ref>Frank McLynn, Genghis Khan. DaCapo Press (2015), 322-327.</ref>

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Decades after this Crusade, Mongol ruler Hulegu Khan would take a census of the Kingdom of Georgia to ascertain how many troops it could muster. According to contemporary sources, the kingdom was judged to be able to field nine tumens.<ref>M.F. Brosset, \"Historie de la Georgie,\" I (St. Petersburg, 1849), pp. 548-549.</ref> A tumen was nominally 10,000 men, but usually averaged 5,000 in reality.<ref>David Morgan, \"The Mongols,\" 1986, p. 72. Morgan expresses skepticism that a tumen actually consisted of 10,000 men and notes that most were 3,000 to 7,000 men.</ref> If Hulegu's census was accurate, then the kingdom of Georgia in the 13th century was capable of mustering 45,000 soldiers. Had a force this size joined the Fifth Crusade, it would have more than doubled the Crusaders' strength.

The first to take up the cross in the Fifth Crusade was King [[Andrew II of Hungary]].<ref>[[Alexander Mikaberidze]]: ''Conflict and Conquest in the Islamic World: A Historical Encyclopedia'', Volume 1 (page 311)</ref> In July 1217, Andrew departed from [[Zagreb]], accompanied by [[Leopold VI of Austria]] and [[Otto I, Duke of Merania]].{{sfn
column8: p=133}} King Andrew's army was so large{{mdash}}at least 10,000 mounted soldiers and even much more \"uncountable\" infantrymen{{mdash}}that most of it stayed behind when Andrew and his men embarked in Split two months later.{{sfn
column14: pp=147–148}} They were transported by the [[Republic of Venice
column15: Venetian]] fleet, which was the largest European fleet in the era. {{sfn
column18: p=297}} Andrew and his troops embarked on 23 August 1217, in [[Split, Croatia
column19: Split]]. They landed on 9 October on [[Cyprus]] from where they sailed to [[Acre, Israel
column20: Acre]] and joined [[John of Brienne]], ruler of the [[Kingdom of Jerusalem]], [[Hugh I of Cyprus]], and Prince [[Bohemond IV of Antioch]] to fight against the [[Ayyubids]] in [[Syria]]. Until his return to Hungary, King Andrew remained the leader of Christian forces in the Fifth Crusade.<ref>Thomas Keightley, Dionysius Lardner: ''Outlines of history: from the earliest period to the present time'' (page 210)</ref> In October 1217, the leaders of the crusaders - Masters of Hospitallers, Templars and Teutonic knights with the leaders and dignitaries of the crusade - held a war council in Acre, over which King Andrew II presided.<ref>Kenneth M. Setton, Norman P. Zacour, Harry W. Hazard: ''A History of the Crusades: The Impact of the Crusades on the Near East'' (page 358)</ref>

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: King Andrew's well-mounted army defeated sultan [[Al-Adil I]] at [[Bethsaida]] on the [[Jordan River]] on 10 November 1217. Muslim forces retreated in their fortresses and towns. In Jerusalem, the walls and fortifications were demolished to prevent the Christians from being able to defend the city, if they did manage to reach it and take it. Muslims fled the city, afraid that there would be a repeat of the bloodbath of the [[First Crusade]] in 1099. The crusaders' catapults and [[trebuchet]]s did not arrive in time, so they had fruitless assaults on the fortresses of the [[Lebanon]] and on [[Mount Tabor]]. Afterwards, Andrew spent his time collecting alleged relics. At the beginning of 1218 Andrew, who was very sick, decided to return to Hungary.<ref>(Jean Richard: ''The Crusades'', c 1071-c. 1291) page 298.</ref><ref name=Howard>{{cite book
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: title= The Crusades: A History of One of the Most Epic Military Campaigns of All Time
column5: publisher= BookCaps Study Guides [for Kindle; Golgotha Press for paperback]

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Andrew and his army departed to Hungary in February 1218, and Bohemund and Hugh also returned home.<ref name=Howard/>
Later in 1218 Oliver of Cologne arrived with a new German army and the count of Holland [[William I, Count of Holland
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: William I]] arrived with a mixed army consisting of [[Dutch people
column5: Frisian]] soldiers. With Leopold and John they discussed attacking [[Damietta]] in Egypt. To accomplish this, they allied with [[Keykavus I]], Seljuq Sultan of Rum in [[Anatolia]], who attacked the Ayyubids in Syria in an attempt to free the Crusaders from fighting on two fronts.<ref>{{cite book
column7: title=The 14th and Final Crusade to the Middle East: Crusades from the 11th Century to the 21st Century
column15: title= A Clash of Thrones: The Power-crazed Medieval Kings, Popes and Emperors of Europe
column23: title= Afghanistan's Experiences: The History of the Most Horrifying Events Involving Politics, Religion, and Terrorism

2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: title= Franks and Saracens: Reality and Fantasy in the Crusades and Terrorism

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In July 1218 the crusaders began their [[Siege of Damietta (1218–19)
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: siege of Damietta]], and despite resistance from the unprepared sultan [[Al-Adil]], the tower outside the city was taken on August 25. They could not gain Damietta itself, and in the ensuing months diseases killed many of the crusaders, including [[Robert of Courçon]]. Al-Adil also died and was succeeded by [[Al-Kamil]]. Meanwhile, Honorius III sent [[Pelagius of Albano]] to lead the crusade in 1219 . Al-Kamil tried to negotiate peace with the crusaders. He offered to trade [[Damietta]] for [[Jerusalem]], but Pelagius would not accept these offers. After hearing this [[William I, Count of Holland]] left the crusade and sailed home.  In August or September, [[Francis of Assisi]] arrived in the crusader camp and crossed over to preach to Al-Kamil. By November, the crusaders had worn out the sultan's forces, and were finally able to occupy the port.

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Immediately the papal and secular powers fought for control of the town, with [[John of Brienne]] claiming it for himself in 1220. Pelagius would not accept this, and John returned to Acre later that year. Pelagius hoped Frederick II would arrive with a fresh army, but he never did; instead, after a year of inactivity in both Syria and Egypt, [[John of Brienne]] returned.

Then in July 1221, excited by rumors that the army of one King David, a descendant of the legendary [[Prester John]], was on its way from the east to the Holy Land to join the crusade, the crusaders at Damietta marched south towards [[Cairo]].<ref>Christopher Eric Taylor, ''Waiting for Prester John: The Legend, the Fifth Crusade, and Medieval Christian Holy War'', 2011, University of Texas at Austin.</ref> This move was observed by the forces of Al-Kamil, and frequent raids along the flanks of the army led to the withdrawal of some 2000 German troops who refused to continue the advance and returned to Damietta.

By now Al-Kamil was able to ally with the other [[Ayyubid]]s in Syria, who had defeated [[Keykavus I]]. The crusader march to [[Cairo]] was disastrous; the river [[Nile]] flooded ahead of them, stopping the crusader advance. A dry canal that they had previously crossed by flooded, thus blocking the crusader army's retreat. With supplies dwindling, a forced retreat began, culminating in a nighttime attack by Al-Kamil which resulted in a great number of crusader losses and eventually in the surrender of the army under Pelagius.

The terms of this surrender meant the relinquishing of [[Damietta]] to Al-Kamil in exchange for the release of the crusaders. Al-Kamil agreed to an eight-year peace agreement with Europe and to return a piece of the [[True Cross]]. However, the relic was never returned as Al-Kamil did not, in fact, have it.

The failure of the Crusade caused an outpouring of anti-papal sentiment from the [[Occitan]] poet [[Guilhem Figueira]]. The more orthodox [[Gormonda de Monpeslier]] responded to Figueira's ''D'un sirventes far'' with a song of her own, ''Greu m'es a durar''. Instead of blaming Pelagius or the Papacy, she laid the blame on the \"foolishness\" of the wicked.

The ''[[Palästinalied]]'' is a famous lyric poem by [[Walther von der Vogelweide]] written in [[Middle High German]] describing a [[pilgrim]] travelling to the [[Holy Land]] during the height of the Fifth Crusade.<ref>Kaye, Haley Caroline, \"The Troubadours and the Song of the Crusades\" (2016).Senior Projects Spring 2016.Paper 280. http://digitalcommons.bard.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1171&context=senproj_s2016. (Pages 70-77)</ref>
*Cassidy-Welch, Megan. ''War and Memory at the Time of the Fifth Crusade''. Pennsylvania State University Press, 2019.
*Donovan, Joseph P. ''Pelagius and the Fifth Crusade''. University of Pennsylvania Press, 2016 [1950].
*Perry, Guy. ''John of Brienne: King of Jerusalem, Emperor of Constantinople, c. 1175–1237''. Cambridge University Press, 2013.
*Powell, James M. ''Anatomy of a Crusade, 1213–1221''. University of Pennsylvania Press, 1986.

2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Tolan, John V.]] ''Saint Francis and the Sultan: The Curious History of a Christian–Muslim Encounter''. Oxford University Press, 2009.

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: *Van Cleve, Thomas C. \"The Fifth Crusade\". [http://digital.library.wisc.edu/1711.dl/History.CrusTwo ''History of the Crusades, Vol. 2: The Later Crusades, 1189–1311''], eds. R. L. Wolff and H. W. Hazard, pp. 376–428. Madison, Wisconsin: University of Wisconsin Press, 1969.

*Veszprémy, László. [http://www.mgh-bibliothek.de/dokumente/b/b068710.pdf \"The Crusade of Andrew II, King of Hungary, 1217–1218\".] ''Iacobus: revista de estudios jacobeos y medievales'' '''13''' (2002): 87–110.

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: '''Kavya Madhavan''' (born 19 September 1984) is an Indian film actress, who appears predominantly in [[Malayalam film]]s while having appeared in a few [[Tamil cinema
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Tamil]] productions. She made her debut in 1991 as a child artist in ''[[Pookkalam Varavayi]]''. Her debut role as a lead actress was in [[Lal Jose]]'s ''[[Chandranudikkunna Dikhil]]'' in 1999, when she was in the ninth grade. column5: accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref> It was produced by Paul Butler of the UK indie rock band [[The Bees (UK band)
column6: The Bees]] in The Steam Rooms, a basement studio in his house in [[Ventnor]] on the [[Isle of Wight]].<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Paul Butler & Michael Kiwanuka: Recording Home Again

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: The album garnered a positive reception from critics. ''Home Again'' peaked at number 4 in the UK and spawned four [[Single (music)
column3: Home Again]]\", \"[[I'm Getting Ready]]\", \"[[I'll Get Along (song)
column4: I'll Get Along]]\" and \"[[Bones (Michael Kiwanuka song)
column5: Bones]]\". As of May 2012, the album has sold over 70,000 copies in the UK.<ref name=\"May2012\">{{cite magazine

2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Home Again]]\" was released as Kiwanuka's debut single on January 1, 2012. The song peaked to number 29 on the [[UK Singles Chart]].

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: * \"[[I'm Getting Ready]]\" was released as the album's second single on March 11, 2012. The song peaked at number 187 on the [[UK Singles Chart]].

column4: title=Michael Kiwanuka – 'I'll Get Along' Video Exclusive On Vevo

title=Album Review: Michael Kiwanuka - Home Again

column10: title=Michael Kiwanuka, Home Again, CD review

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: ''Home Again'' received positive reviews from [[Music journalism
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: music critic]]s. At [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[Standard score
column3: normalized]] rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the album received an [[Weighted mean
column4: average]] score of 72, based on 25 reviews.<ref name=\"Metacritic\"/>

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Alexis Petredis of ''[[The Guardian]]'' gave high praise to Butler's production for capturing early '70s soul music and Kiwanuka's vocals and lyrics for feeling authentic, saying that, \"''Home Again''{{'}}s strength lies in the fact that it manages to tick a lot of boxes without sounding like it set out to tick a lot of boxes.\"<ref name=\"Guardian\"/> Gareth James of ''[[Clash (magazine)
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Clash]]'' also praised Butler for his soft, acoustic production and compared Kiwanuka's vocals positively to [[Bill Withers]], calling the album \"an absolute treat for fans of rootsy vintage soul and a remarkable statement of intent for a debut release.\"<ref name=\"Clash\"/> Helen Brown of ''[[The Daily Telegraph
column3: The Telegraph]]'' praised the production aesthetics for sounding complex and easy-going, saying that, \"Despite its lyrical portrait of a constant worrier who feels lost and lonely, ''Home Again'' is a remarkably assured and sophisticated album.\"<ref name=\"Telegraph\"/> Hilary Saunders of ''[[Paste (magazine)
column4: Paste]]'' admired Kiwanuka's vocals and lyrics for resembling '70s soul artists like [[Otis Redding]] and [[Marvin Gaye]], concluding with, \"On ''Home Again'', the young Kiwanuka proves that youth and wisdom are not mutually exclusive and his insights and talents, albeit still a bit raw, suggest great things to come.\"<ref name=\"Paste\"/>

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Thom Jurek of [[AllMusic]] noted that Butler's vintage sounding production felt paint-by-numbers at times and Kiwanuka's lyrical content needed fine-tuning, concluding with, \"Despite difficulties, ''Home Again'' is a promising debut by an artist who will no doubt deliver big if developed properly.\"<ref name=\"AM\"/> Andy Gill of ''[[The Independent]]'' also found Kiwanuka's vocals and lyrics needing a bit more urgency and edge to them but called the album \"a pleasant enough handful of easy-going songs, in which the focus on warmth has left them lacking bite.\"<ref name=\"Independent\"/> Emily Mackay of ''[[NME]]'' questioned the album's lack of gritty lyrics and false authenticity but said there were tracks that felt like genuine work, concluding that \"''Home Again'' provides a sumptuously soft place for tired ears to rest. Enough for many, for now, and a good start.\"<ref name=\"NME\"/> Aaron Lavery of [[Drowned in Sound]] felt the album was depressing at times but said that \"[I]t’s a minor quibble however, of a record that has clearly been crafted with great care and a terrific talent behind both the songwriting and the production.\"<ref name=\"DiS\"/>

2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: title9  = Any Day Will Do Fine

column4: title=MICHAEL KIWANUKA - Diskografie - Home Again (Deluxe Edition) - Album, CD - CDs, Discography - Universal Music}}</ref>

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: '''Victoria Jackson''' (born August 2, 1959)<ref name=\"filmref 1\"/> is an [[United States
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: American]] actress, comedian, and singer who was a cast member of the [[NBC]] television [[sketch comedy]] series ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' (SNL) from 1986 to 1992.

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Jackson was born in [[Miami, Florida]], the daughter of Marlene Esther (née Blackstad) and James McCaslin Jackson, a gym coach.<ref name=\"filmref 1\">{{cite web
column6: accessdate=March 27, 2010}}</ref> From the age of 5 until she was 18, Jackson's father trained her in gymnastics.<ref name=\"Tenessean2014\">{{cite news
column8: title=Victoria Jackson's values no laughing matter

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: After graduating from high school, Jackson attended Florida Bible College in [[Hollywood, Florida]], later transferring to [[Furman University]] in [[Greenville, South Carolina]] on a gymnastics scholarship. At Furman, she was cast in her first play. She transferred to [[Auburn University]] in 1979 for her senior year, changing her major to theater. Midway through her senior year, she left Auburn to pursue an acting career.<ref name=\"Tenessean2014\" /><ref>{{cite news
column4: title=SNL alum Victoria Jackson's year at Auburn

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In the 2000s, Jackson earned a degree in theatre from [[Palm Beach Atlantic University]].<ref name=\"NewTimes\" />

While doing summer stock theater in Alabama, Jackson met former child actor [[Johnny Crawford]] of the 1950s television series ''[[The Rifleman]]'', who cast her in his nightclub act. She moved to Los Angeles in 1981,<ref name=LAT1084>{{cite news
column4: title=Bottom Lines: Gymnast-Actress and Fire-Eating Musician Make Their Dreams Come True
column6: date=16 August 1984}}</ref> working various day jobs and performing comedy at night.<ref name=tulsaworld/><ref name=Globe1984>{{cite news
column9: title=Adventures in the L.A. skim trade
column14: title='Rainbow Of Comedy' Coming To San Diego: Stand-Up Comics Set For Old Globe Stand-Up Comics
column17: quote=Opening for each of these headliners is an assortment of lesser-known stand-ups. ranging from ... comic poet-acrobat Victoria Jackson,...}}</ref> Her first big break was an appearance on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]'', where she recited poetry while doing a handstand.<ref name=tulsaworld/><ref>{{cite news
column26: title='Tonight Show' Special: Women, 19 Cents A Pound
column28: date=19 August 1984}}</ref> She went on to appear on the show 20 times.<ref name=tulsaworld/>  In 1984 she appeared in the pilot for ''[[W*A*L*T*E*R]]'', a ''[[M*A*S*H (TV series)
column29: M*A*S*H]]'' spin-off that the networks did not pick up.<ref>{{Citation

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Following a role in the short-lived 1985 television series ''[[Half Nelson (TV series)
column6: accessdate=7 January 2018}}</ref> Jackson received an offer to audition for the cast of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. Because she was not confident her audition had gone well, she performed several impersonations on her next ''Tonight Show'' appearance and sent the tape to ''SNL''{{'}}s [[Lorne Michaels]]. After viewing the tape, Michaels asked Jackson to join the show.<ref name=Casual/><ref>{{cite book
column11: title=Live From New York: The Complete, Uncensored History of Saturday Night Live as Told by Its Stars, Writers, and Guests
column17: language=en}}</ref> A regular cast member from 1986 to 1992,<ref name=Herald2005/> Jackson often appeared on the show's weekly ''[[Weekend Update]]'' segment as a correspondent who would go off topic, reciting poetry and doing backbends or handstands on the desk.<ref name=NewTimes/><ref name=Casual/> She was also known for recurring skit roles where she would impersonate [[Roseanne Barr]] or [[Zsa Zsa Gabor]].<ref name=NewTimes/>

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: During her tenure on ''SNL'', Jackson was cast in a number of films, including ''[[Baby Boom (film)
column3: Family Business]]'', ''[[I Love You to Death]]'',<ref name=Herald2005/> ''[[UHF (film)
column8: title=Movie Reviews: 'Pick-up Artist' Meets His Match
column19: title=A Christian Fundamentalist Disrobes For ''Casual Sex?''
column24: language=en}}</ref> Her film career continued after her 1992 departure from ''Saturday Night Live'', but mostly in unknown or unnoticed films.<ref name=\"filmref 1\" /> On television, she was cast as the lead of her own sitcom, co-starring [[George Clooney]]. When there was a change in management at Fox, the show was scrapped without being broadcast.<ref name=\"tulsaworld\">{{cite news
column26: title='SNL' alum brings stand-up routine to Tulsa club
column30: newspaper=[[Tulsa World]]}}</ref> In 1994, she appeared as \"Beverly\" in the ''[[In the Heat of the Night (TV series)
column32: title=In the Heat of the Night, Season 7, Episode 13 Good Cop, Bad Cop
column36: language=en}}</ref> episode \"Good Cop, Bad Cop\", and in 2000 she appeared as the unrequited love of a small-town man who can control the weather in ''[[The X-Files]]'' episode \"[[The Rain King (The X-Files)
column40: title=The End and the Beginning: The Official Guide to the X-Files Season 6

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Jackson had a regular role in the 2003–04 seasons of the Nickelodeon show ''[[Romeo!]]''.<ref name=Herald2005>{{cite news
column4: title=Ex-'SNL' star Victoria Jackson balances career, motherhood
column8: language=en}}</ref> In 2004 and 2005, she had roles in two romantic comedies, ''[[Shut Up and Kiss Me (film)
column9: Shut Up and Kiss Me!]]'' and ''[[Her Minor Thing]]''.<ref name=Herald2005/> During this period, Jackson appeared on the game show ''[[Hollywood Squares]]'' and participated in the show ''[[Celebrity Fit Club (U.S. TV series)
column10: Celebrity Fit Club]]''.<ref name=Herald2005/> She played multiple characters in the 2014 [[direct-to-video]] movie ''Campin' Buddies''.<ref name=Stokes>{{cite news

column20: title=Nothing says \"garbage movie\" like Victoria Jackson in 7 different roles

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In 2016, Jackson had a role in ''[[The Matchbreaker (2016 film)

A self-described conservative Christian, Jackson has appeared in productions such as the 2007 [[Christian comedy]] concert ''Thou Shalt Laugh 2: The Deuce''<ref name=CBN/> as well as a dozen times on ''[[Politically Incorrect]]'' with [[Bill Maher]] as the \"token religious conservative\".<ref name=Herald2005/> She has supported the [[Tea Party movement]] through appearances at events as well as her website, which was affiliated with the [[Liberty Alliance, LLC
column5: title=Building God's Kingdom: Inside the World of Christian Reconstruction

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In October 2008, she appeared with other celebrities on ''[[The O'Reilly Factor]]'' in a [[National Republican Senatorial Committee]] advertisement poking fun at [[Al Franken]], a fellow ''Saturday Night Live'' alumnus then running for the United States Senate from Minnesota.<ref>{{cite news
Beginning in 2008, Jackson stated that she believed [[Barack Obama]] to be a communist.<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=Demonizing a President: The \"Foreignization\" of Barack Obama: The \"Foreignization\" of Barack Obama

column31: title=Victoria Jackson's excellent Tea Party adventure

column40: date=26 January 2012}}</ref> In 2015, she spread [[Barack Obama religion conspiracy theories
column41: conspiracy theories about Obama's religion]], saying he was an \"[[Islam]]ic [[jihad]]ist\" who supported the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant
column42: Islamic State]], that he had [[Muslim Brotherhood]] members in his cabinet, and that Obama's support for legal [[abortion]] and [[same-sex marriage]] showed he was not a Christian.<ref>{{cite web
column45: title=Victoria Jackson: Obama's Gay Marriage Support Proves He's 'An Islamic Jihadist'
column55: title= Former \"SNL\" cast member Victoria Jackson: Obama is \"an Islamic jihadist\"
column64: title=Victoria Jackson: Obama Part of Muslim Brotherhood

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In 2011, Jackson criticized the TV show ''[[Glee (TV series)
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Glee]]'' for showing a kiss between two male actors, citing the [[Bible]] to justify her criticism. When accused of [[homophobia]], Jackson countered that the label was merely a \"cute liberal buzzword\" and suggested that ''Glee'' be replaced with a show promoting celibacy.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title = Victoria Jackson: Homophobic a 'Cute Little Buzzword'

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In 2011, Jackson joined the staff of ''Patriot Update'' as a writer and video blogger and host of the talk show ''Politichicks''. Co-hosts included Ann-Marie Murrell, Jannique Stewart, and Jennie Jones.<ref name=Miami>{{cite news
column13: date=December 13, 2011}}</ref> Jackson wrote a satirical song for  \"Politichicks\" titled \"Shariah Law\", with the song's lyrics claiming, \"They [Muslims] like beheadings and pedophile weddings\".<ref name=Miami/> Among her work for Patriot Update was a piece on [[Occupy Wall Street]] that was critical of the protesters.<ref>{{cite news
column16: title=Victoria Jackson brings opinions about Obama and Jesus to Occupy Wall Street (Video)
column20: title=Occupy Wall Street: Former 'SNL' Actress Victoria Jackson Grills Protesters (Video)

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In 2012, White Hall publishers, part of the Liberty Alliance, released Jackson's autobiography, ''Is My Bow Too Big? How I went from Saturday Night Live to the Tea Party''.<ref name=Ingersoll/><ref>{{cite news
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: title=Bookmarks: Recent publications from Furman writers
column8: title=Can Victoria Jackson return from the fringe?

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In 2012, after [[Todd Akin]]'s remarks regarding pregnancies resulting from [[rape]], Jackson said, \"If I got raped, I would have the baby. And if I didn't want to keep it because I had these horrible nightmares, I would adopt it out. But I think that God can turn a bad thing into a good thing, and that if I got raped and a beautiful baby who was innocent was born out of it, that would be a blessing.\"<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Former 'SNL' Star Makes Shocking Comments About Rape And Gay Friends

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In 2014, Jackson filed a petition as an independent candidate for one of two District 2 seats in [[Williamson County, Tennessee]]. She received 632 votes, not enough to secure either seat against the incumbent candidates.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Former SNL star Victoria Jackson officially files for county commission
column9: title='SNL's Victoria Jackson falls to incumbents

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Jackson married a fellow performer, fire-eating magician Nisan Mark Eventoff, in 1984,<ref name=LAT1084/> and had a daughter, Scarlet (born 1986).  They divorced in 1991.<ref name=NewTimes/> Shortly thereafter, she reconnected with her high school sweetheart, Paul Wessel then a Miami-Dade SWAT team police officer, and they married and had a daughter, Aubrey (born 1994).<ref name=Tenessean2014/> When her husband retired in 2013, the couple moved to Nashville, Tennessee.<ref name=Tenessean2014/><ref name=CBN>{{cite news
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: title=Victoria Jackson: Funny Begins with Faith

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Jackson was diagnosed with Stage 3 [[breast cancer]] in October 2015, and underwent a double [[mastectomy]] and [[chemotherapy]]. In 2017, BroadStreet Publishing released a comedy/devotional book, about Jackson's cancer journey, ''Lavender Hair.''

column11: title=Live From New York: The Complete, Uncensored History of Saturday Night Live as Told by Its Stars, Writers, and Guests
column17: language=en}}</ref> A regular cast member from 1986 to 1992,<ref name=Herald2005/> Jackson often appeared on the show's weekly ''[[Weekend Update]]'' segment as a correspondent who would go off topic, reciting poetry and doing backbends or handstands on the desk.<ref name=NewTimes/><ref name=Casual/> She was also known for recurring skit roles where she would impersonate [[Roseanne Barr]] or [[Zsa Zsa Gabor]].<ref name=NewTimes/>

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: During her tenure on ''SNL'', Jackson was cast in a number of films, including ''[[Baby Boom (film)
column3: Family Business]]'', ''[[I Love You to Death]]'',<ref name=Herald2005/> ''[[UHF (film)
column8: title=Movie Reviews: 'Pick-up Artist' Meets His Match
column19: title=A Christian Fundamentalist Disrobes For ''Casual Sex?''
column24: language=en}}</ref> Her film career continued after her 1992 departure from ''Saturday Night Live'', but mostly in unknown or unnoticed films.<ref name=\"filmref 1\" /> On television, she was cast as the lead of her own sitcom, co-starring [[George Clooney]]. When there was a change in management at Fox, the show was scrapped without being broadcast.<ref name=\"tulsaworld\">{{cite news
column26: title='SNL' alum brings stand-up routine to Tulsa club
column30: newspaper=[[Tulsa World]]}}</ref> In 1994, she appeared as \"Beverly\" in the ''[[In the Heat of the Night (TV series)
column31: In the Heat of the Night]]''<ref>{{cite web
column32: title=In the Heat of the Night, Season 7, Episode 13 Good Cop, Bad Cop
column36: language=en}}</ref> episode \"Good Cop, Bad Cop\", and in 2000 she appeared as the unrequited love of a small-town man who can control the weather in ''[[The X-Files]]'' episode \"[[The Rain King (The X-Files)
column40: title=The End and the Beginning: The Official Guide to the X-Files Season 6

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Jackson had a regular role in the 2003–04 seasons of the Nickelodeon show ''[[Romeo!]]''.<ref name=Herald2005>{{cite news
column4: title=Ex-'SNL' star Victoria Jackson balances career, motherhood
column8: language=en}}</ref> In 2004 and 2005, she had roles in two romantic comedies, ''[[Shut Up and Kiss Me (film)
column9: Shut Up and Kiss Me!]]'' and ''[[Her Minor Thing]]''.<ref name=Herald2005/> During this period, Jackson appeared on the game show ''[[Hollywood Squares]]'' and participated in the show ''[[Celebrity Fit Club (U.S. TV series)
column10: Celebrity Fit Club]]''.<ref name=Herald2005/> She played multiple characters in the 2014 [[direct-to-video]] movie ''Campin' Buddies''.<ref name=Stokes>{{cite news
column13: title=Victoria Jackson talks Tea Party, Zanies show
column20: title=Nothing says \"garbage movie\" like Victoria Jackson in 7 different roles

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In 2016, Jackson had a role in ''[[The Matchbreaker (2016 film)

A self-described conservative Christian, Jackson has appeared in productions such as the 2007 [[Christian comedy]] concert ''Thou Shalt Laugh 2: The Deuce''<ref name=CBN/> as well as a dozen times on ''[[Politically Incorrect]]'' with [[Bill Maher]] as the \"token religious conservative\".<ref name=Herald2005/> She has supported the [[Tea Party movement]] through appearances at events as well as her website, which was affiliated with the [[Liberty Alliance, LLC
column5: title=Building God's Kingdom: Inside the World of Christian Reconstruction

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In October 2008, she appeared with other celebrities on ''[[The O'Reilly Factor]]'' in a [[National Republican Senatorial Committee]] advertisement poking fun at [[Al Franken]], a fellow ''Saturday Night Live'' alumnus then running for the United States Senate from Minnesota.<ref>{{cite news
Beginning in 2008, Jackson stated that she believed [[Barack Obama]] to be a communist.<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=Demonizing a President: The \"Foreignization\" of Barack Obama: The \"Foreignization\" of Barack Obama
column15: title=Former SNL Member Victoria Jackson: Obama A \"Communist,\" Like \"Castro In Cuba, The Guy In China\"
column24: title=Victoria Jackson On Fox News: Obama Is A Communist, Rush Limbaugh Should Run The Country
column31: title=Victoria Jackson's excellent Tea Party adventure
column37: title=Victoria Jackson Says New Times Profile of Her Was Lies Penned by a Socialist (Updated)
column40: date=26 January 2012}}</ref> In 2015, she spread [[Barack Obama religion conspiracy theories
column41: conspiracy theories about Obama's religion]], saying he was an \"[[Islam]]ic [[jihad]]ist\" who supported the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant
column42: Islamic State]], that he had [[Muslim Brotherhood]] members in his cabinet, and that Obama's support for legal [[abortion]] and [[same-sex marriage]] showed he was not a Christian.<ref>{{cite web
column45: title=Victoria Jackson: Obama's Gay Marriage Support Proves He's 'An Islamic Jihadist'
column55: title= Former \"SNL\" cast member Victoria Jackson: Obama is \"an Islamic jihadist\"
column64: title=Victoria Jackson: Obama Part of Muslim Brotherhood

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In 2011, Jackson criticized the TV show ''[[Glee (TV series)
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Glee]]'' for showing a kiss between two male actors, citing the [[Bible]] to justify her criticism. When accused of [[homophobia]], Jackson countered that the label was merely a \"cute liberal buzzword\" and suggested that ''Glee'' be replaced with a show promoting celibacy.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title = Victoria Jackson: Homophobic a 'Cute Little Buzzword'

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In 2011, Jackson joined the staff of ''Patriot Update'' as a writer and video blogger and host of the talk show ''Politichicks''. Co-hosts included Ann-Marie Murrell, Jannique Stewart, and Jennie Jones.<ref name=Miami>{{cite news
column13: date=December 13, 2011}}</ref> Jackson wrote a satirical song for  \"Politichicks\" titled \"Shariah Law\", with the song's lyrics claiming, \"They [Muslims] like beheadings and pedophile weddings\".<ref name=Miami/> Among her work for Patriot Update was a piece on [[Occupy Wall Street]] that was critical of the protesters.<ref>{{cite news
column16: title=Victoria Jackson brings opinions about Obama and Jesus to Occupy Wall Street (Video)
column20: title=Occupy Wall Street: Former 'SNL' Actress Victoria Jackson Grills Protesters (Video)

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In 2012, White Hall publishers, part of the Liberty Alliance, released Jackson's autobiography, ''Is My Bow Too Big? How I went from Saturday Night Live to the Tea Party''.<ref name=Ingersoll/><ref>{{cite news
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: title=Bookmarks: Recent publications from Furman writers
column8: title=Can Victoria Jackson return from the fringe?

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In 2012, after [[Todd Akin]]'s remarks regarding pregnancies resulting from [[rape]], Jackson said, \"If I got raped, I would have the baby. And if I didn't want to keep it because I had these horrible nightmares, I would adopt it out. But I think that God can turn a bad thing into a good thing, and that if I got raped and a beautiful baby who was innocent was born out of it, that would be a blessing.\"<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Former 'SNL' Star Makes Shocking Comments About Rape And Gay Friends

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In 2014, Jackson filed a petition as an independent candidate for one of two District 2 seats in [[Williamson County, Tennessee]]. She received 632 votes, not enough to secure either seat against the incumbent candidates.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Former SNL star Victoria Jackson officially files for county commission
column9: title='SNL's Victoria Jackson falls to incumbents

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Jackson married a fellow performer, fire-eating magician Nisan Mark Eventoff, in 1984,<ref name=LAT1084/> and had a daughter, Scarlet (born 1986).  They divorced in 1991.<ref name=NewTimes/> Shortly thereafter, she reconnected with her high school sweetheart, Paul Wessel then a Miami-Dade SWAT team police officer, and they married and had a daughter, Aubrey (born 1994).<ref name=Tenessean2014/> When her husband retired in 2013, the couple moved to Nashville, Tennessee.<ref name=Tenessean2014/><ref name=CBN>{{cite news
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: title=Victoria Jackson: Funny Begins with Faith

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Jackson was diagnosed with Stage 3 [[breast cancer]] in October 2015, and underwent a double [[mastectomy]] and [[chemotherapy]]. In 2017, BroadStreet Publishing released a comedy/devotional book, about Jackson's cancer journey, ''Lavender Hair.''
*''[[In the Heat of the Night (TV series)

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: The sixth season of the American television drama series ''[[Homeland (TV series)
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Homeland]]'' premiered on January 15, 2017, and concluded on April 9, 2017, on [[Showtime (TV network)
column3: Showtime]], consisting of 12 episodes.<ref name=\"6predate\">{{cite web
column5: title=''Homeland'' Season 6, ''Billions'' Season 2 Get Premiere Dates at Showtime
column10: accessdate=August 11, 2016}}</ref> The series started as a loosely based variation of the two-season run of the [[Israel]]i television series ''[[Prisoners of War (TV series)
column11: Hatufim]]'' (English: ''Prisoners of War'') created by [[Gideon Raff]] and is developed for American television by [[Howard Gordon]] and [[Alex Gansa]].<ref name=hatifum>{{cite web
column15: accessdate=December 30, 2011}}</ref> The sixth season was released on Blu-ray and DVD on February 6, 2018.<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Homeland - New Release Date, Package Art, and Bonus Material for 'The Complete 6th Season'

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: Taking place several months after the previous season, [[Carrie Mathison]] is back in the United States, living in Brooklyn, New York with her young pre-school aged daughter. She is now working at a foundation whose efforts are to provide aid to Muslims living in the United States. Peter Quinn is alive but has suffered a major stroke and is incapacitated but seemingly, turned to a junkie. Saul Berenson and Dar Adal are still CIA operatives and are dealing with counter-terrorism within the United States. The season features the results of a presidential election of a female candidate, and takes place between [[Election Day (United States)
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: election day]] and [[United States presidential inauguration
column5: title=‘Homeland’ Nears Renewal For Seasons 7 & 8, Season 6 Debut Pushed To January

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: The season’s episodes’ opening includes excerpts from ''[[The Revolution Will Not Be Televised]]''.
On December 9, 2015, the series was renewed for a sixth season.<ref>{{cite web
column8: accessdate=December 9, 2015}}</ref> On August 11, 2016, at the [[Television Critics Association
column9: 2016 Summer TCA Press Tour]] it was announced that filming of the season would begin in August 2016, in New York.<ref name=\"season6details\"/> Showrunners [[Alex Gansa]] and [[Howard Gordon]] along with [[Gideon Raff]], [[Chip Johannessen]], Michael Klick, Patrick Harbinson, [[Lesli Linka Glatter]], [[Avi Nir]], Ran Telem, and [[Claire Danes]] are executive producers.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=‘Homeland’ Sets Season 6 Premiere Date, Schedules ‘Billions’ Season 2 Return

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: In September 2016, co-star [[Rupert Friend]] sustained an injury to his foot, forcing production to shoot around his character Peter Quinn. Despite the setback, his sabbatical is not expected to affect the premiere date. Also announced that month, while the majority of shooting and plot will take place in [[New York City]], production will be returning to film scenes in [[Morocco]] (subbing for [[Abu Dhabi]] and [[Israel]]); where the series has not filmed since the third year.<ref name=\"FriendHurt\">{{cite news
column3: title=‘Homeland’ Shuffles Season 6 Production After Co-Star Rupert Friend Gets Injured
column8: accessdate=September 20, 2016}}</ref> A promotional poster and a behind-the-scenes video was released on November 17, 2016.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=‘Homeland’ Heads ‘Home’ in Full Season 6 Featurette and Poster

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: On July 27, 2016, [[Elizabeth Marvel]] was cast in the role of Elizabeth Keane, a senator from New York who was just elected to be the next President of the United States.<ref name=\"ElizabethMarvel\"/> On August 10, 2016, it was announced that [[Hill Harper]] and [[Patrick Sabongui]] joined the cast.<ref name=\"HillPatrickroles\"/> On August 16, 2016, [[Robert Knepper]] joined the cast in the recurring role of General Jamie McClendon, the [[United States Department of Defense
2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: Department of Defense]] representative.<ref name=\"Rbertknepperrole\"/> On September 10, 2016, it was announced that [[Dominic Fumusa]] had joined as [[FBI Special Agent]] Ray Conlin.<ref name=\"fumusa\" />

,safe,Ss112,"{{short description: The sixth season of ''Homeland'' has received generally positive reviews from critics. On [[Metacritic]], the season has a score of 68 out of 100 based on 15 reviews.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=March 30, 2017}}</ref> On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], it has an approval rating of 78% with an average rating of 7.32 out of 10 based on 28 reviews. The site's critical consensus is, \"''Homeland'' delivers introspective comfort food with a satisfyingly strong leading female character and storylines that continue to surprise.\"<ref>{{cite web

2020 single by Camila Cabello featuring: America First]]\", and Outstanding Sound Editing for a Series for \"America First\". This is the first season in which [[Claire Danes]] has not been nominated for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Drama Series.<ref>{{cite web
